item.title: BBC's deceit over Diana interview worsened my parents' relationship - William
item.description: The prince speaks of "indescribable sadness" caused by his mother's interview with Martin Bashir.

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian ceasefire comes into effect
item.description: The ceasefire brings to an end 11 days of fighting in which more than 240 people were killed.

item.title: 'BBC failures contributed to paranoia and isolation'
item.description: Princess Diana was failed not just by Martin Bashir but also by leaders at the BBC, says Prince William.

item.title: Prince Harry says heavy drinking masked pain of mum Diana's death
item.description: Prince Harry also says he was willing to turn to drugs to cope with grief, and had panic attacks.

item.title: Covid-19: Stillbirth risk may increase with virus and review of Scotland's levels due
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday morning.

item.title: Covid: Stillbirth and prematurity risks may be higher
item.description: A study suggests that while the overall risks remain low, coronavirus may increase stillbirths.

item.title: Mayhill: Swansea rioters face robust action, police vow
item.description: One man spoke of how a "mob" turned on him, throwing bricks at his family and their home in Swansea.

item.title: Contaminated blood inquiry: Matt Hancock to give evidence
item.description: The health secretary will face questions about compensation for victims of contaminated blood on Friday.

item.title: Schools set to lose £118m funding for poor pupils
item.description: Pupils who became eligible between October 2020 and January 2021 will not now be counted until October 2021.

item.title: Retail sales soar in April as shops reopen
item.description: There was a big jump in clothing sales last month as shoppers returned to the High Street.

item.title: Higher plastic bag charge comes into force in England
item.description: Single-use plastic carrier bags in English shops now cost 10p, twice the previous price.

item.title: Author Hilary Mantel says UK needs written constitution
item.description: The Wolf Hall writer bases her views on Boris Johnson's 2019 attempt to suspend Parliament.

item.title: The Papers: Princes' 'rage and sadness' at BBC 'lies' to Diana
item.description: The findings of an inquiry into a BBC interview with Princess Diana dominates Friday's front pages.

item.title: George Nkencho killing: 'The door closed and then I heard the shots'
item.description: George Nkencho was shot dead by police officers outside his Dublin home in December 2020.

item.title: Quiz of the week: Eurovision, Ariana Grande and the 99
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: India Covid: Dying mother's final message
item.description: Dimple Arora was a 34 year-old-dentist with everything to live for when she died of Covid-19.

item.title: Shopping centres face demolition after Covid
item.description: Covid has worsened the crisis for shopping centres; what can be done with the spaces?

item.title: Friends: 7 things the trailer reveals about the reunion
item.description: Including guest stars, emotional moments, set visits, table reads and Phoebe's singing.

item.title: Worcestershire detectorist finds stolen treasures on first hunt
item.description: Charles Cartwright dug up a hoard of Roman and Viking jewellery taken in a burglary four years ago.

item.title: Mayra Zulfiqar: Family appeal for justice
item.description: 25-year-old Mayra Zulfiqar was shot in Lahore earlier this month and her family is appealing for justice.

item.title: Meet the YouTubers who stood for mayor of London
item.description: Niko Omilana and Max Fosh are two prominent YouTubers who stood for London mayor at the election.

item.title: St Ives: 'Unluckiest' swan becomes a mum after raft rescue
item.description: A boatyard worker was determined the swan's eggs would hatch after watching them fail for 10 years.

item.title: Biden chides graduates to clap: 'You're really dull'
item.description: The president prods coast guards to applaud him. But did Reagan deliver the same line better?

item.title: The Venezuelans fleeing to Colombia to avoid fighting
item.description: Thousands have fled intense armed clashes which involve Venezuela’s army and Colombia’s rebel groups.

item.title: Councillors reject Bridgerton film set in Windsor park
item.description: Netflix wants to build a film set for its hit series near ancient woodland on Crown Estate land.

item.title: Butlin's resorts back open for business
item.description: Butlin's holiday resort in Skegness, Lincolnshire, welcomed back visitors and staff this week.

item.title: Sixteen-year-olds try to break into China's livestream market
item.description: Xiao Yu is hoping for a career in livestream selling, an industry expected to grow to a value of £200bn in 2021.

item.title: Wedding joy for Warwickshire couple amid cancer treatment
item.description: Owen Murray and Laura Dear tied the knot in front of 30 guests at a ceremony.

item.title: Severely ill - and still made to quarantine in a hotel
item.description: The law says some severely ill are exempt from hotel quarantine - but they don't always get a choice.

item.title: Covid: Australia's vaccine hesitancy worries medical experts
item.description: Medical experts are concerned that low Covid infection rates may be leading to complacency.

item.title: Olivia Rodrigo has become pop's brightest new star - here's how
item.description: She seemingly arrived from nowhere, but the Drivers License singer has been preparing for this all her life.

item.title: Eurovision: TIX, Tourettes and mental health
item.description: Norway's Eurovision entry has come to this years competition with more than music on the agenda.

item.title: Teaching artificial intelligence to control navy submarines
item.description: Submarines controlled by artificial intelligence are being designed to take on military missions.

item.title: 'I pay more than £9,000 a year for my season ticket'
item.description: As rail reforms loom, commuters tell the BBC about the problems they face with UK train services.

item.title: UK-Australia trade deal: What are the arguments for and against?
item.description: The government wants to finalise negotiations by early June.

item.title: Rail reform: What does the shake-up mean for you?
item.description: How will a government promise to simplify the UK's "complicated" rail network impact passengers and fares.

item.title: McIlroy falters on Kiawah Island return as Conners takes first-round lead
item.description: Rory McIlroy, champion at Kiawah Island in 2012, ends round one on three over, eight behind Canadian leader Corey Conners, who is two clear of the field on five under.

item.title: Sergio Aguero: From 'worst trainer in the world' to Man City 'icon'
item.description: As Sergio Aguero prepares for his final Premier League appearance as a Manchester City player, his former team-mates discuss his impact.

item.title: BBC Sport and Sky Sports unite over online hate
item.description: BBC Sport and Sky Sports come together to amplify their stance on online abuse as part of the ‘Hate Won’t Win’ campaign.

item.title: Champions League final: Should Uefa be more flexible about host cities for environmental reasons?
item.description: Consecutive Champions League finals have now been moved because of Covid, but should environmental concerns become a key factor in the staging of major matches?

item.title: 'This is the evolution of a sport - it doesn't happen overnight'
item.description: Teenage Wasps prop Maud Muir is looking at a possible future as a full-time professional England player. For her director of rugby Giselle Mather, things were very different.

item.title: Anthony Joshua v Tyson Fury: Deontay Wilder won't step aside from Tyson Fury fight - Bob Arum
item.description: Deontay Wilder will not step aside to allow Tyson Fury to fight Anthony Joshua in August, Fury's promoter Bob Arum says.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in Northern Ireland, following rule changes in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 37 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Lockdown easing: Virus experts tell us what they will (and won't) be doing
item.description: How will scientists use their new-found freedoms when Covid restrictions are eased on Monday?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People in their 20s and 30s are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the UK rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Can two households travel in one car? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccines: Why some African states can't use their vaccines
item.description: African countries have struggled to get vaccines, but some now plan to throw away thousands of doses.

item.title: Covid Indian variant: Where is it, how does it spread and is it more infectious?
item.description: B.1.617.2 is dominant in some parts of the country - but it doesn't have to be cause for panic yet.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: In some parts of the UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant from India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: India variant: Why was India not put on the red list sooner?
item.description: India was put on the travel ban list two weeks after Pakistan and Bangladesh.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.
